review.title: Quality Estimation of English-Hindi Outputs using Naive Bayes Classifier
review.abstract: In this paper we present an approach for estimating the quality of machine translation system. There are various methods for estimating the quality of output sentences, but in this paper we focus on Na\"ive Bayes classifier to build model using features which are extracted from the input sentences. These features are used for finding the likelihood of each of the sentences of the training data which are then further used for determining the scores of the test data. On the basis of these scores we determine the class labels of the test data.

sections.text: Keywords - Quality Assessment, Confidence Assessment, Naive Bayes.I. INTRODUCTION In this paper, we have examined the Machine Translation Confidence Assessment, in which we find the quality ratings of sentences. The main objective of the Confidence Assessment is to assess the behavior of the system output for a given input, without information about the expected output. Confidence Assessment for Machine Translation can be considered a binary classification problem in order to distinguish between "good" and "bad" translations. The remaining section of the essay is structured as follows: Section 2 gives an overview of previous work on quality assessment. Section 3 describes the methodology of the system. Section 4 gives the experimental settings. Section 5 describes the analysis and the results. Section 6 finally gives you the conclusion.

sections.heading: II. RELATED WORK
sections.text: Blatz.et al. [1] presents a series of experiments with CE at the sentence level, based on annotations that use automatic MT evaluation metrics. Repressors and classifiers are trained on characteristics extracted for translations labeled as "good" according to the National Institute of Standard and Technology (NIST) and Word Error Rate (WER). For the classification, NIST values are used as a threshold to designate the 5th or 30th percentile of examples as "good." For regression, the estimated values are mapped into two classes using the same thresholds. Results did not show that they are helpful in a number of evaluation tasks. Quirk [2] uses classifiers and a predefined threshold for "bad" and "good" translations, which take into account a small set of 350 manually labeled translations in terms of quality. Specia et al. [3] use a number of "black boxes" (MT system independent) and "glass system-dependent" squartz (MT) characteristics.

sections.heading: B. Working of the system
sections.text: Naïve Bayes is a well-known algorithm for classification problems. The list of sets of attribute values and their corresponding category is given to the classifier and these form the training set. An independent probability is determined from the training data. The probability indicates the probability of each target class, taking into account the occurrence of each value category from each input variable. When a new example is presented, a value for the target function can be predicted based on the training instances. 1 Training Steps - Using the training samples, the methods estimate the parameter of a probability distribution, provided the characteristics are conditionally independent of the class. 2 Test Steps - For each invisible test sample, the method calculates the posterior probability of this sample belonging to each class.Enter Algorithmic Steps Sets Features are extracted from these input sets. sections.text: For the evaluation of the system, we converted the human evaluation of the system into grades. These grades are in Table III. The results of the classifier are calculated on the basis of those grades that gave us the same grade.

sections.text: The results of the naive Bavarian classifier and the human evaluation are presented in Table 4. This indicates the number of machine translation machine evaluations in each of the four categories. Table 5 shows the results of the human evaluation for all three MT engines. These four evaluations can also be converted into a numerical evaluation to evaluate the results of the MT. Table 6 shows the comparison of the results of the human evaluation with the grades given by the classifier. If a human evaluator gave a good evaluation to a sentence and the classifier also gave a good grade to the same sentence, then it is counted. More, the human evaluator and the classifier can achieve almost similar results to most other judgments.

sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: In this paper, we have extracted 16 features from the introductory sentences and their translation and obtained a quality assessment based on Bayesian conclusions from training data. In this paper, we have shown that the Naïve Bayes Classifier can predict the same level of results as the human evaluator. Furthermore, in the future, we will improve the quality of the system by adding a few more features and examining and evaluating the system by comparing the rankings of the system given by the human being. The system that receives the same ranking as the human being is considered the good system.

referenceMentions.context: [1] presents a number of experiments with CE at the sentence level based on annotations using automatic MT evaluation metrics.
Quirk [2] uses classifiers and a pre-defined threshold for “bad” and “good” translations considering a small set of 350 translations manually labeled for quality.

[3] use a number of “black box” (MT systemindependent) and “glass-box” (MT systemdependent) features to train a Partial Least Squares (PLS) regression algorithm to estimate both NIST and human scores.
[4] trained an SVM classifier using a number of linguistic features which were extracted from machine and human translations to differentiate between human and machine translations.
[5] used a regression algorithm along with features which contained textual entailment between the translation and the reference sentences.
Soricut and Echihabi [6] focus on document level CE.
[7] used 74 features to train a support vector machine classifier.
